title: In Situ Insight into MXene Oxidation Process via Closed-Cell Transmission Electron Microscopy under Near-Atmospheric Pressure
content: Two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials garnered widespread attention due to their exceptional physicochemical properties. MXene, a 2D transition metal carbides, nitrides, or carbonitrides, has emerged as a star material owing to its outstanding metallic conductivity, tunable chemical functionalities, remarkable mechanical properties, and unique surface chemistry [1, 2]. With surpassing performance compared to traditional metal oxides, MXene is highly promising for energy storage devices such as batteries and supercapacitors [3], as well as flexible electronics and structural components due to its outstanding mechanical strength and flexibility [4]. However, MXene is highly susceptible to oxidation, which results in performance degradation. Although this is a long-standing problem for the stability and performance of MXene, the oxidation mechanism for MXene remains not well studied. To close this knowledge gap, a controlled, real-time observation at nanoscale is required.
